part.title: Accidentals
part.para: Accidental signs are marks placed before a notehead to indicate that the pitch of the note should be altered. At level 1 you should know about three signs: the 'sharp', the 'flat' and the 'natural':

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (text ''sharp'' dx:20 dy:70) (spacer 20) (n +g4 q)(n +c5 q) (spacer 20)(barline double) (spacer 20) (text ''flat'' dx:0 dy:70) (n -g4 q)(n -c5 q) (spacer 20)(barline double) (spacer 20) (text ''natural'' dx:0 dy:70) (n =g4 q)(n =c5 q) (spacer 20)(barline end) )))

part.para: A sharp sign raises the pitch of a note by a half step (one semitone). A flat sign lowers the pitch of a note a half step (one semitone). A natural sign cancels the effect of a flat or a sharp.

The accidental sign alters the pitch of the note that it is attached to, but also any subsequent occurence of the same note in the same measure. Notes in the new measure will not be altered except those tied to one in the previous measure. Also, notes with the same pitch name, but higher or lower octave will not be be affected.

part.title: Key signature
part.para: Having to write accidentals always in the same notes can be annoying. If, for example, a piece of music is written based on the D major scale, all F and C notes will have sharp signs placed before them. For example:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4) (spacer 20) (n d4 q)(n e4 q)(barline simple) (n +f4 q)(n g4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n b4 q)(barline simple) (n +c5 q)(n d5 q)(barline simple) (n d4 q)(n +f4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n d5 q) (spacer 20) (barline end) )))

part.para: To make the writing process easier, instead of writing sharp signs before all F and C notes, the accidentals can be written at the beginning of the staff, immediately after the clef sign. These accidentals affect the whole score and are named the 'key signature'. They apply to all relevant notes in every octave. As a consequence, is no longer needed to place accidental signs in front of each note. So, the previous score can also be written as follows:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key D) (time 2 4) (spacer 20) (n d4 q)(n e4 q)(barline simple) (n f4 q)(n g4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n b4 q)(barline simple) (n c5 q)(n d5 q)(barline simple) (n d4 q)(n f4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n d5 q) (spacer 20) (barline end) )))

part.para: Note that the sharp for F note is placed on the 5th line but it affects all F notes, independently of the octave.

The key signature, apart of simplifying the notation, gives information about the 'tonality' of the composition, that is, roughly speaking, which scale is used to build a piece of music. The key signature must be written on every music line, placed immediately after the clef sign.
